Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: A Multidisciplinary Research Experience in Engineered Bioactive Interfaces and Devices

Division.LongName: Div Of Engineering Education and Centers

Award.AbstractNarration:
BROADER SIGNIFICANCE OF THE PROJECT:

The overall objective of this project is to provide a novel multidisciplinary research and education experience for rising sophomore, junior and senior undergraduates in the area of Engineered Bioactive Interfaces and Devices. Research in Engineered Bioactive Interfaces and Devices focuses on the novel design of architectures that interact with biological systems and promote a desired response. These advanced architectures have numerous applications including tissue engineering, sensing systems, and drug delivery. Students will be recruited from various undergraduate disciplines including engineering, biology, chemistry, physics and mathematics. Surrounding the University of Kentucky are numerous regional colleges and universities that have no graduate programs in these areas. Recruitment at these institutions will encourage students that may not otherwise pursue an advanced degree. In addition, recruitment for the program will focus on national institutions that do not have graduate programs. Special efforts will be made to attract women and minorities to this program by recruiting at minority institutions and publicizing the program at national meetings of minority and women organizations such as the Society of Women Engineers and the National Society of Black Engineers. Students accepted into the program will work closely with faculty and graduate students who are currently engaged in collaborative, cross-disciplinary research. The proposed REU program builds on these successful collaborations and integrates them with other educational components, such as seminars, workshops, and other technical and social activities. The students will be exposed to the excitement of interdisciplinary research and by the end of the program will have an excellent knowledge of what is involved in graduate research.


PROJECT DESCRIPTION:

The area of Engineered Bioactive Interfaces focuses on the novel design of architectures that interact with biological systems and promote a desired response. The need for this cross-disciplinary interaction between investigators working in biological systems and those creating novel engineered synthetic architectures has long been recognized. These advanced architectures have numerous applications ranging from tissue engineering to sensing systems to drug delivery. Successful development of these systems will depend on expertise not only in developing novel synthetic architectures through nanotechnology, self-assembly and hybrid systems but also on the interactions of these interfaces with biological systems such as cells and proteins. As part of the REU program, the undergraduate students will have the opportunity to learn about three cross-disciplinary research themes that form the foundation of the research in this area. These areas include 1) "Novel Bioactive Architectures", 2) "Cell/Protein Interactions at Interfaces", and 3) "Integration into Devices". The students will work closely with faculty and graduate students who are currently engaged in collaborative, cross-disciplinary research across these three themes further supporting a highly multidisciplinary team research approach. This REU Program will not only provide the students with true interdisciplinary mentoring and research training but will also stimulate the students' interests in Ph.D. careers in science and engineering through seminars, field trips and interactions with both graduate students and faculty, and will develop the students independence and confidence through participation in research and presentations both in house and at scientific meetings.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The overall goal of this project was to provide a novel multidisciplinary research and education experience for rising sophomore,  junior and senior undergraduates in the area of Engineered Bioactive Interfaces and Devices. Over this nine years of funding, we provided  the opportunity for over 114 students to participate in multidisciplinary undergraduate research experience.  The students not only interacted with REU faculty but also interacted with graduate trainees through research, special seminars, and other technical and social activities.  Specific objectives of the program included 1) provide the students with true interdisciplinary mentoring and research training through their participation in a research project related to Engineered Bioactive Interfaces and Devices 2) stimulate the students’ interests in Ph.D. careers in science and engineering through seminars, field trips and interactions with both graduate students and faculty, and 3) develop the students’ independence and confidence through participation in research, brainstorming sessions, and presentations both in house and at scientific meetings.

 The students were assigned a primary advisor and a co-advisor and met with both advisors weekly. At the beginning,  the students were required to present a short overview of their research project. Prior to their presentation, they were required to complete a Goal Sheet where they had to state the primary hypothesis of their research, the critical experiments needed to test the hypothesis, and two notable outcomes expected to accomplish during the summer.  After 4 weeks, they were required to complete a mid-summer evaluation of goals.  Finally at the end of the program, the students completed a final evaluation of goals. In addition to faculty advisors, REU students were assigned a laboratory mentor. This mentor met with the students on a daily basis and actively guided them on their research projects. The lab mentors attended all the REU presentations and were also invited to attend all social activities. 

Students were also provided graduate students. This mentor was different from the lab mentor and worked in a lab that was different from the REU student's lab. Through this mentor each REU student not only received research mentoring from his/her lab mentor but also received general type mentoring from other graduate students that were not directly associated with the research project. The graduate student mentors attended all presentations and assisted the REU students with preparation of their presentations.  The REU students also met with their graduate student mentor every other week in an informal setting during lunch so that they had the opportunity to discuss informally any concerns or questions they had about career opportunities, graduate school or the progression of their research.

Each student was  also required to present a research update.  These sessions occurred at the middle of the program.  The students presented their research progress to date and also discussed challenges that they had encountered.   Finally, all REU students participated in a poster competition/awards banquet at the end of the program.

The REU students also attended a seminar each week to learn about various aspects related to graduate school and research.  Finally, the students participated in outside activities including a tour of Alltech Biotechnology and a number of social activities.

The program ended with a poster competition and awards banquet.  The students were encouraged to invite their parents and other family.  Each student received a certificate for participating in the program and other awards were given such as best poster, best blog and best research update. 

Each year, we successfully recruited 12 - 16 outstanding students to our REU Program.  The average GPA of these students was a 3.8.  The students came from universities all over the nation and schools were targeted where students may not receive a research opportunity.   A large percentage of the participants (60%) were women and (30%) were either African American, Hispanic or Asian/Pacific Islander. 

One of the major objectives of this program is to stimulate the students’ interests in Ph.D. careers in science and engineering.  Prior to participating in the REU program, 40% said they were definitely going to graduate school and the rest said they were not certain. After participating in the REU Program 70% said they were definitely going to graduate school and 30% maybe.   Another objective of this program was to develop the students’ independence and confidence through participation in research, in house presentations, and scientific meetings.   Prior to this program, very few of the students had prior research experience. All of the students commented that their presentations skills improved after participating in the REU Program.  As part of the REU Program, each student was provided with $800 to attend a scientific conference to present his or her research.  The majority of the students took advantage of this opportunity and presented at least one oral or poster presentation at a regional or national meeting.  A number of them won awards in oral or poster competitions .
